title: 104_hr4016
content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The Secretary reserves a percentage of funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, as well as for programs for Indian youth. Additionally, an amount not exceeding $1,000,000 may be reserved for national purposes. The Secretary of the Interior reserves funds for programs for Indian youth, with a maximum of $1,000,000 for national impact evaluation. Additionally, 0.2 percent of the amount is reserved for programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are allocated based on the school-aged population of each State. The allocation of funds to states under subsection (a) is based on the school-aged population ratio and the amount received under part A of title I in the previous year. Each state is guaranteed a minimum of one-half of 1 percent of the total amount allotted. The Secretary may reallot funds to a State if it cannot use the amount within two years. Reallotments are based on the same criteria as initial allotments. The term 'State' refers to each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The term 'local educational agency' includes educational service agencies and consortia of such agencies. "State applications are outlined in SEC. 4112." The chief executive officer of the State must submit an application to the Secretary to receive an allotment under section 4111 for any fiscal year. The application must describe how funds will be coordinated with programs under various Acts, including the Goals 2000: Educate America Act, and contain the results of the State's needs assessment for drug and violence prevention programs. The State must submit an application to the Secretary for drug and violence prevention programs, based on ongoing evaluation activities and data on drug use and violence by youth. The application must also include an assurance of cooperation for a national impact evaluation and any other required information. The Secretary will use a peer review process for reviewing State applications. State programs for drug and violence prevention require an application to the Secretary, including data on youth drug use and violence, cooperation for national impact evaluation, and peer review of State applications. The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs, with a limit of 5% for administrative costs. Grants and contracts are exclusively for financing these programs. The allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs must be used exclusively for prevention or education programs dedicated to teaching the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. Funds should not be used for any other purposes. The allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs must be used exclusively for prevention or education programs dedicated to teaching the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. Expenditures for purposes other than a strict no-drug-use curriculum will be considered a violation, with penalties including forfeiture and reimbursement. Grants or contracts awarded under this subsection will be subject to a peer review process. The chief executive officer of a State may carry out drug abuse and violence prevention activities directly or through grants or contracts. Funds under subsection (a)(1) will be used to award grants to law enforcement agencies in partnership with educational or community-based agencies for prevention activities. The text chunk discusses funding for drug abuse and violence prevention activities, including programs like Project Drug Abuse Resistance Education and Project Legal Lives. These programs involve classroom instruction by law enforcement officials and district attorneys to teach students to resist pressures to use controlled substances or alcohol and educate them about the legal system. District attorneys provide classroom instruction in the law and legal system, emphasizing interactive learning techniques like mock trial competitions, partnerships with law enforcement and child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. "District attorneys provide classroom instruction in the law and legal system, emphasizing interactive learning techniques like mock trial competitions, partnerships with law enforcement and child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary conducts a biennial evaluation of national impact of programs to combat violence in schools, submitting findings to the President and Congress. The National Center for Education Statistics collects data for this purpose. The National Center for Education Statistics collects data on violence in elementary and secondary schools for a report to Congress with recommendations and estimated costs by January 1, 2000. The chief executive officer of each State must submit a report to the Secretary every third year on the implementation and effectiveness of State programs under section 4113, following the specified format and based on ongoing evaluations. The chief executive officer of each State must submit a report to the Secretary every third year on the implementation and effectiveness of State programs under section 4113. The report shall be in the form specified by the Secretary, based on ongoing evaluation activities, including data on drug use and violence by youth, and made readily available to the public. "Programs for Native Hawaiians under SEC. 4114." The Secretary will provide grants or agreements to organizations serving Native Hawaiians for programs authorized by this title. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to the area before 1778. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to individuals with ancestors who were natives of the area now comprising the State of Hawaii before 1778.
